Award.AwardTitle: Slow Light Enhanced Mid-infrared Nonlinear Optical Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to conduct experimental investigation of novel nonlinear material and
waveguide designs and to develop a compact, integrated photonic device platform for nonlinear optical
devices operating in the mid-infrared spectral region. There is a current dearth of nonlinear optical
devices in the mid-infrared and the proposed research program aims to fill this void.
The intellectual merits are: (1) novel device architecture for slow light propagation with low loss and (2)
new tunable light sources and amplifiers for the mid-infrared frequency region. The slow light devices
are based on photonic crystals to enable dispersion engineering necessary for slow light but has radically
different designs to circumvent the fundamental limits imposed by scattering loss. Additionally, the
devices will be implemented in a chalcogenide material system, with high nonlinearity and Raman gain,
long infrared transparency, and a high glass transition temperature.
The broader impacts are many. First, the proposed work will broadly impact the applied physics and
materials science world by providing a new class of devices based on nonlinear-enhancement from slow
light. The capability of ultralow threshold for nonlinearities will open a wide application space for the use
of
devices with standard, low cost lasers. The potential to demonstrate a low-threshold nonlinear optical
device in the mid-infrared will be transformative for applications in sensing, spectroscopy,
communications, medicine and more. The project is also designed to integrate research with education at
both undergraduate and graduate levels, attract underrepresented minority students, and offer outreach to
general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has developed chalcogenide based photonic devices for nonlinear optical devices operating in the infrared region. The infrared spectrum, which represents the region of frequency lower than the visible spectrum, contains rich optical signatures arising from molecular vibrations. It is therefore possible to identify molecules or materials by conducting spectroscopy in the infrared region. For this reason, the infrared region is sometimes called the molecular fingerprint region. This, however, has not yet been fully realized due to several technical challenges which include the lack of efficient light sources and the lack of efficiency and compact photonic devices.

 

This project addresses these challenges by developing chalcogenide-based photonic devices. Chalcogenide refers to a compound containing chalcogen element such as sulfur, selenium and tellurium. Chalcogenides are excellent materials for infrared photonic devices thanks to their high transparency and high nonlinearity. While the materials have been known for a long time, it is only recently they are considered for compact devices with on-chip geometry. It is therefore necessary to develop fabrication processes optimized for chalcogenide devices, which was one of the major activities undertaken in this project. By using electron-beam and photo-lithography techniques and new etching recipes, we fabricated high quality chalcogenide waveguides and resonators. We also developed optical characterization setup with which we measured very low loss in the waveguides and high quality factors in the resonators.

 

These devices provide the technical foundation for high sensitivity optical sensors that can perform ultralow level detection and molecular identification. These devices can be used for environmental sensing of pollutants and climate change gases, explosive and other hazardous material detection, gas sensing for chemical process engineering, to name a few. Furthermore, the compact geometry will allow the devices to be incorporated in portable electronic devices that are becoming increasingly ubiquitous. Combined with the emerging technologies of portable electronics and internet of things, the new sensors could fundamentally change how sensing is done and impact our society in a wide variety of different ways. The project has also provided research opportunities and individualized mentoring to three graduate students, one undergraduate student and two postdoctoral researchers. It has also contributed to graduate level courses on active optical devices and optical electronics.
